screen.translation[0].definitions[0].def: the part of a television or computer where the picture or information appears
screen.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: a computer with an 18-inch colour screen
He went on staring at the TV screen.
Her picture appeared on the screen.
It’s easy to change the text on screen before printing it.
screen.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the large white surface that pictures are shown on in a cinema
screen.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: He was horrified at some of the images he saw on the screen.
screen.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: This is the first time the play has been adapted for the big screen  (=films).
a star of stage and screen  (=the theatre and films)
screen.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a piece of furniture like a thin wall that can be moved around and is used to divide one part of a room from another
screen.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: There was a screen around his bed.
screen.translation[0].definitions[4].def: something tall and wide that hides a place or thing
screen.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: The house was hidden behind a screen of bushes.
screen.translation[0].definitions[5].def: something that hides what someone is doing
screen.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The business was just a screen for his drug-dealing activities.
screen.translation[0].definitions[6].def: a medical test to see whether someone has an illness
screen.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: The company is offering a free health screen to all employees.
screen.translation[0].definitions[7].def: a wire net fastened inside a frame in front of a window or door to keep insects out
screen.translation[0].definitions[8].def: a decorative wall in some churches
screen.translation[0].definitions[9].def: a player in a game such as basketball who protects the player who has the ball
screen.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to do tests on a lot of people to find out whether they have a particular illness
screen.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: All women over 50 will be regularly screened.
It is now possible to screen babies for diabetes.
screen.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if something screens something else, it is in front of it and hides it
screen.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: A line of trees screened the house from the road.
screen.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to show a film or television programme
screen.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: The film is being screened around the country.
The match will be screened live on television.
screen.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to find out information about people in order to decide whether you can trust them
screen.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: Police are very careful when screening politicians’ bodyguards.
screen.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to check things to see whether they are acceptable or suitable
screen.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: You can use an answerphone to screen your phone calls before you answer them.
screen.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to test people or examine their past history to make sure that they are suitable for something, for example to work for a particular organization
screen.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Applicants for teaching posts must be carefully screened.
All employees are screened for drugs.
screen.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to test or check something to make sure that it is suitable, does not break the law etc
screen.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Imported fish should be screened for disease.
screen.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to show a film or television programme
screen.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: The ad was screened late at night on Channel 4.
screen.translation[3].definitions[0].def: the flat glass part of a computer or television
screen.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: The customer’s account details are displayed on the screen.
Of the two flat-screen models, the more expensive one was clearly better.
screen.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: It’s easy to change the text on screen before printing it.
